title: Noah and Universal Covenant
objective: Identify covenant preservation themes in the flood narrative

segments.audio_script: This is lesson six. You are studying Noah and universal covenant. Lesson five examined covenant curse in the fall narrative.

Human sin spreads across creation. Genesis 6 describes escalating rebellion. God responds with judgment through flood. But God preserves a remnant through Noah. This pattern of judgment and preservation shapes biblical narrative.

The flood is covenant judgment—consequence of sustained rebellion. But Noah finds grace. God specifies covenant stipulations for preservation. After flood, God establishes a new covenant with Noah explicitly named.

Key themes: Noahic covenant is universal—applies to all humanity. Divine promise is unconditional. Rainbow is covenant sign. Judgment and preservation coexist. God maintains purpose despite human failure.
What does God establish with Noah after the flood?
segments.correct_answer: A universal covenant with the sign of the rainbow
acceptable_variants: Promise never to flood the earth again

segments.audio_script: This completes lesson six. You studied covenant preservation through Noah. Next lesson examines Abraham and covenant promise.

vocabulary.definition: God's universal covenant with Noah promising preservation of creation and never to destroy the earth by flood
A visible symbol of God's covenant commitment to a people

study_notes: The Noahic covenant is foundational for understanding God's commitment to creation. It bridges the fall judgment and the particular Abrahamic covenant.
